Appointed Hinkley Prof Which It 'Is Sure Of Winning'

Dr. Norman Gash, Professor
of History at University of St.
Andrews, Scotland, has been appointed the John Hinkley Memorial Visiting Professor at The
Johns Hopkins University for the
second semester of the current
academic year. Dr. Gash, an
eminent scholar in English constitutional history, will arrive in
Baltimore sometime after the
first of the year, according to
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, Hopkins' president.

I

While at Hopkins, Dr. Gash
will give one lecture a week, lead
special seminars and consult with
students in the social sciences
and humanities who have special
interest in pre-law studies and
constitutional history. He will
give at least one public lecture
of interest to members of the
legal profession in Baltimore.
John Hinkley
The John Hinkley Memorial
Visiting Professorship was established by the estate of Miss Mary
Keehmle Hinkley as a memorial
to her brother, Mr. John Hinkley, who died in 1940.
A distinguished Baltimore lawyer, and graduate of The Johns
Hopkins Univeristy, Mr. Hinkley
was a legal scholar of international reputation. He had particular interest in the legal constitutional history of England,

6

and the role of the English legal
and judicial tradition in the
origin and development of American law and jurisprudence.

The Hinkley visiting professor
is chosen each year by a committee composed of chairmen of
the Hopkins' departments of
History, English, Political Science
and Political Economy. In addition the Chief Judge of the Supreme Bench of Baltimore City,
or a representative appointed by
him is also a member of the
selection committee. In select(Continued on Page 3)

By KEN NOBEL
The D.S.R.C. touched off a
campus power struggle at its
meeting last week when it failed
to recognize the Student Council's rejection of its newly devised judicial system.
The D.S.R.C. decided to proceed with the establishment of
a dormitory judicial board despite the refusal of the Student
Council to approve it. The Student Council's rejection was
based on the fact that the constitution of the board could be
changed without the approval of
the dormitory students.
In setting up the judiciary
board without the approval of the
Student Council, the D.S.R.C.
tacitly accepted the fact that
this would involve them in a
"power struggle" to determine
whether the D.S.R.C. was "a
group with its own constitution"
or a "puppet of the Student
Council." One member of the
D.S.R.C. stated that "This is a
power struggle and we (the
D.S.R.C.) have more jurisdiction
over dorm students than they
do." Another member commened that "They're afraid of us."
He saw the question at issue as
"who is the parent organization."
Pete Abeson, President of the
D.S.R.C., reminded the members
in the middle of the debate that

interset'At Shriver Hall
"Winterset" by Maxwell Anderson will be presented by the Barnstormers December 1 and 2 in
Shriver Hall.
An alumnus of Loyola, Bob Dunn, will direct
the annual winter play. No admission will be
charged. Leads in the play include Pete Grossman, Judy Blank, Mike Sundermeyer, Bob Landau, Bert Routman, and Kostia Bergman.
Briefly the plot is as follows:
A payroll is robbed. A man is killed. The
culprit is apprehended and tried by the community. The verdict: guilty. Justice has been
rendered by due process of law. But has it?
What about the fact that the evidence was purely
circumstantial, and that the condemned man
was a foreigner and an anarchist. But all appeals
are denied and the man is executed. Years later
the case is closed, even forgotten; for the public
believes that guilt is found only when no reasonable doubt exists. But then why does the judge
walk the streets like a madman, stopping people
with arguments? Why does a witness to the robbery who was never called to the stand fear for

Shriver Hall To Host
Lecture By Dr. Asimov
Dr. Isaac Asimov, well-known
biochemist and science-fiction
writer, will give an address here
on December 8th entitled: "A
BRAND-NEW END OF THE
EARTH." The talk will be given
in Shriver Hall at ten o'clock
on Friday.
Dr. Asimov is presently an
Associate Professor of Biochemistry at the Boston University
School of Medicine. He was born
in the U.S.S.R. in 1920 and came
to the United States in 1923. In
1928 he became a United States
citizen. Dr. Asimov was educated
in the New York public school
system and later went to Columbia University. He received all
of his degrees from Columbia,
including a B.S. in 1939, an M.A.
in 1941 and a Ph. D. in 1948. In
1949 he joined the faculty of
the Boston University School of
Medicine.
Dr. Asimov began writing in
1938, but until 1950 his works
were published solely in science
fiction magazines. His first book,

PEBBLE IN THE SKY, was
published in 1950. Up to now
he has written a total of fortytwo books, the last of which,
REALM OF ALGEBRA, was
published in September, 1961.
(Continued on Page 3)

Lone Sophomore
Wins Television
In PM Contest
Dan Rosenfelt, Campus Student Representative for the
Philip Morris Company, announced last week that Harris
Belman and Phi Kappa Psi fraternity have won first and second prize, respectively, in the
"Round Up" contest which ended
November 16.
Heiman, a sophomore and a
resident of Baltimore, turned in
more than 4,000 empty cigarette
packages thereby winning a 19"
portable television set. When
asked by the News-Letter how
he managed to accumulate so
many packs, Heiman explained
that he encouraged all his friends
and relatives to collect empty
packages for him and that all
his empty packs were gathered
during the five week period of
the contest.
In awarding the television set
to Belman and a portable stereo
to Phi Kappa Psi, Dan Rosenfelt
noted that the individual initiative of Harris Heiman and the
members of Phi Kappa Psi had
prevailed over the efforts of much
larger groups. He added that
future Philip Morris promotions
will endeavor to encourage individual rather than group effort.

Concert Scheduled
By Hopkins And
GoucherGleeClubs
The combined glee clubs of
The Johns Hopkins University
and Goucher College will present their annual concert of
Christmas music Sunday, December 3, 8:30 p.m. in JHU's
Shriver Hall.
Featured on the program will
be the first Baltimore performance of Healey Willan's "An
Apostrophe to the Heavenly
Hosts." Also on the program will
be Marc Antoine Charpentier's
"Messe de Minuit" and "A
Canticle of Christmas" by Vittorio Giannini.
The "Canticle" features an
unusual final fugue in which
the audience participates by
singing the basic theme of "0
Come All Ye Faithful,"
The Hopkins and Goucher glee
clubs are directed by James W.
Mitchell and Robert Hall Lewis,
respectively. Soloists appearing
will be John Carpenter and
Felipe Lebron of Hopkins, and
Hope Tompkins, Carolyn Noon
and Peggy Spense of Goucher.
Gerald Looney, a former Hopkins undergTadute and glee club
soloist, will sing narration of
the "Canticle."
Also participating will be the
Martinet brass ensemble.

rather

order here so that our well meaning
Student Council anti DSRC may reconsider the meaning
of the Code, their relation to it, their responsibility to
the student body, and finally the respect they owe, but
so infrequently show to the students they puport to represent.
In the first place the open jurisdictional conflict
between the DSRC anti the SC reminds one of the behavior of an "arrested adolescent who disarmingly
imagines that he will attain stature if (as short boys are
advised in Dixie) he loads enough manure into his
shoes." The petty jealousies surrounding this childish
squabble are entirely unnecessary and undermine the
very object which both groups seek to attain. The blame
for this sorry state of affairs rests with both groups, and
every effort should be made to cease from this innane
behavior.
Secondly, we note that by relegating the Code to a
trivial level the Council has seriously undermined the
Code's efficacy. The SC activities of the past week are an
example of this. There was no necessity for the Council
to try the petty offense of stealing a flag at a football
game. The very value of the Code lies partly in the
latitude of action it allows a Hopkins student. The Code
should only be invoked when the infraction warrants
serious action. Otherwise there will never be a shred of
respect for the Gentlemen's Code.
The attitude of many SC members in this and other
instances clearly shows their complete detachment from
the reality of student behavior. It should be recognized
that college students do not and cannot act in accordance
with the idealized and unrealistic image of a Gentleman
desired by certain members of our Hopkins community.
The welter of trivia passed in recent years by the SC
and DSRC testify to this fact. If a moral robot is desired
then we should apply to Pavlov and Skinner and abandon
the Gentlemen's Code.
This particularizing of the Gentlenten's Code stems
in part from the undue concern with publicity and public
relations which manifests itself throughout all levels of
the University. A reading of the version of the Gentlemen's Code contained in the present SC constitution reveals that "The Honor system governs... those aspects
of behavior among students on the campus, or at the
location of campus-sponsored activities, which might in
any way compromise or undermine the present valued
ethical concept of Hopkins men." But in the proposed
version of the Gentlemen's Code Commission we find
that its jurisdiction has been enlarged to world wide
coverage extending through all vacations. One wonders
if we won't have to sign out to relieve the University of
responsibility for our behavior after we graduate.
In conclusion we can only reiterate that we do not
disagree with the conception of a campus wide judicial
hoard. On the contrary, we initiated this idea in an editorial last spring. But we do take exception with the concepts and methods being used to accomplish this end.
We would suggest that both the DSRC and SC begin to
think before they act, that they consider the philosophy
underlying the Gentlemen's Code, and that they act appropriately.

Bravo!
The fraternity men among us should react with
pride in regard to the latest listing of their averages.
While the top fraternity has equaled its performance of
last year, the majority of fraternities have considerably
improved their levels of scholarship. A point in fact is
that one fraternity raised its average a tenth of a point
hut dropped two places in the listing. We would also
guess that the overall fraternity average has echoed this
trend and gone up considerably from last year. These
facts should help dispell the well worn conundrum that
membership in a fraternity hurts marks. Quite obviously
the Hopkins fraternities are mark conscious and effectively work to improve their grades.

It is hard to say whether or not Mr. Johns

acquired for his private collection such books as
those entitled Woman Physiologically Considered,
Sleep, and Professional Anecdotes. But the wellknown philanthropist would surely have been delighted to know that many of his rare books will
soon find a home in the school's new, ultramodern library building.

of one thousand volumes, is currently being transferred from the Board of Trustees Room of the

BIA President Cioni
Speaks On Intramurals
By LAWRENCE POLLAK
After successfully completing
its Fall sports program, the
Board of Intramural Athletics,
under President Joe Cioni, is now
getting its winter season into
full swing. The main function
of the BIA is the organization
and operation of an intramural
sports program for fraternities,
dormitory houses, and independents. The Board also serves as
a judicial body, deciding all disputes and protests that occur
during intramural games.
The BIA is a ten member
group made up of three Seniors,
three Juniors, and four Sophomores. During each sport seaBooks for sale—Encyclopedia

Distinguished from that which has practical application, pure research is concerned with the discovery of fundamental
knowledge to widen man's understanding
of himself and the universe.
Ford Motor Company's Scientific Laboratory in Dearborn, Michigan is dedicated
to the pursuit of knowledge in the physical
sciences. On its staff are scientists of
national and international reputation who
conduct independent basic research programs of an extremely broad nature.
Why does Ford Motor Company support
research which seemingly is unrelated to
the manufacture of its products?
It is our view, and a pioneering concept
in our industry, that entirely new approaches to automotive development can
come only from unhampered scientific
investigation. Deeper understanding of
matter itself, and of the conversion and
storage of energy—aside from widening
man's primary knowledge—may have
practical application in tomorrow's vehicle
design.
Thus knowledge wrested from nature by
scientists will be taken by technologists
and applied to serve practical needs and
desires. Another example of Ford's leadership through scientific research and
engineering.

When asked to comment on
the intramural program thus far
this year, President Cioni replied that "generally, things have
been running smoothly" and
that he was quite pleased with
the program. The main criticism
of the BIA so far this year, Cioni
explained, has been that there
hasn't been enough publicity
given to the schedule of the
games and as a result several
teams,
especially
fraternity
teams, did not show up for their
scheduled Fall sports games.
Cioni admitted that the BIA
was partly to blame for the
missed games as a result of poor
publicity, but he added; "Ten
days before the Fall program,
a meeting of all team athletic
managers was held and a schedule for the entire season was
presented; Some of the fraternity athletic managers did not
inform the fraternity of its
schedule of games. In an effort
to correct this, the BIA has
instituted a weekly bulletin,
which, besides listing a schedule
of the week's games, contains
up to date league standings.
Cioni also plans to make up next
Fall's schedule in April or May
to avoid any last minute confusion.
Cioni felt that another weakness in tile fall season was the
officiating. For the Intramural
Basketball games, referees will
be provided and they will be
paid $1.50 by the Athletic Department. Cioni added that he
would like to see the same thing
done in football and lacrosse,
but he felt that the referees
would probably have to be paid
by the teams themselves.
In an attempt to clarify certain BIA rulings, Cioni stated
that there are no forfeits allowed in the Fraternity leagues
and, if a team forfeits 25% of
its games, it will be dropped
from the league. Also, anyone is
eligible for BIA sports in a particular season, if he is not playing an intercollegiate sport in
that season.

Project Soon To Begin
Construction is scheduled to
begin in the very near future
on the expansion and improvement of Levering Hall facilities,
it was announced today by
Wesley A. Taylor, Assistant to

HopkinsUniversity
Releases Non-toxic
Dye in River
On Friday, December 1, a
non-toxic, red fluorescent liquid
dye will be pumped into Round
Bay on the Severn River as part
of a study of water circulation
by the Johns Hopkins University's Chesapeake Bay Institute.
The dye will be released continuously for twenty-one days
from the Institute's research
vessel, the Maury, anchored in
Round Bay.
Dr. Donald W. Pritchard, director of the Institute, said that
the dye will be visible by residents in the area for a few hundred yards from the point of
release. He stated that the color
will not be visible to the eye as
it spreads out into the Chesapeake Bay. The dye is in no
way harmful to people, plants,
or animals. It will not discolor
or harm the paint finish on hulls
of boats.
The dye to be released is a
commercial pigment, rhodamine
B, used in such things as lipstick and pink birthday candles.
As the dye spreads through
the waters of Round Bay, its
concentration and
movement
will be continuously recorded by
two vessels of the Hopkins
Chesapeake Bay Institute, the
Lydia Louise II and the Tracer.
After the dye has been dispersed by the currents, water
will be drawn up through a tube
into the laboratory ships. There
it will pass through an instrument specially designed to measure the concentration of the
dye.
This study is the first in a
projected series of investigations of water movement and
dispersion being conducted by
the Hopkins scientists in order
to gain a better foundation for
understanding what happens to
treated sewage after discharge
into the Chesapeake Bay or one
of its tributaries.
Dr. James H. Carpenter, Hopkins' oceanographer, devised this
method of tagging water with
rhodamine B.
Dr. Carpenter said that oceanographers have carried out
laboratory studies on many
kinds of chemicals to be released
as tagging elements in water
which could be followed for
mile as tile water circulated and
mixed. Some chemicals were
found to be toxic. Others were
too weak to be followed by the
most delicate of detecting instruments. Still others disappeared
too fast. Rhodamine B, has
proved to be non-toxic, longlasting and easily detected for
long periods of time.

Dr. Norman Gash, Professor
of History at University of St.
Andrews, Scotland, has been appointed the John Hinkley Memorial Visiting Professor at The
Johns Hopkins University for the
second semester of the current
academic year. Dr. Gash, an
eminent scholar in English constitutional history, will arrive in
Baltimore sometime after the
first of the year, according to
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, Hopkins' president.

I

While at Hopkins, Dr. Gash
will give one lecture a week, lead
special seminars and consult with
students in the social sciences
and humanities who have special
interest in pre-law studies and
constitutional history. He will
give at least one public lecture
of interest to members of the
legal profession in Baltimore.
John Hinkley
The John Hinkley Memorial
Visiting Professorship was established by the estate of Miss Mary
Keehmle Hinkley as a memorial
to her brother, Mr. John Hinkley, who died in 1940.
A distinguished Baltimore lawyer, and graduate of The Johns
Hopkins Univeristy, Mr. Hinkley
was a legal scholar of international reputation. He had particular interest in the legal constitutional history of England,

6

and the role of the English legal
and judicial tradition in the
origin and development of American law and jurisprudence.

The Hinkley visiting professor
is chosen each year by a committee composed of chairmen of
the Hopkins' departments of
History, English, Political Science
and Political Economy. In addition the Chief Judge of the Supreme Bench of Baltimore City,
or a representative appointed by
him is also a member of the

The D.S.R.C. touched off a
campus power struggle at its
meeting last week when it failed
to recognize the Student Council's rejection of its newly devised judicial system.
The D.S.R.C. decided to proceed with the establishment of
a dormitory judicial board despite the refusal of the Student
Council to approve it. The Student Council's rejection was
based on the fact that the constitution of the board could be
changed without the approval of
the dormitory students.
In setting up the judiciary
board without the approval of the
Student Council, the D.S.R.C.
tacitly accepted the fact that
this would involve them in a
"power struggle" to determine
whether the D.S.R.C. was "a
group with its own constitution"
or a "puppet of the Student
Council." One member of the
D.S.R.C. stated that "This is a
power struggle and we (the
D.S.R.C.) have more jurisdiction
over dorm students than they
do." Another member commened that "They're afraid of us."
He saw the question at issue as
"who is the parent organization."
Pete Abeson, President of the
D.S.R.C., reminded the members
in the middle of the debate that

"Winterset" by Maxwell Anderson will be presented by the Barnstormers December 1 and 2 in
Shriver Hall.
An alumnus of Loyola, Bob Dunn, will direct
the annual winter play. No admission will be
charged. Leads in the play include Pete Grossman, Judy Blank, Mike Sundermeyer, Bob Landau, Bert Routman, and Kostia Bergman.
Briefly the plot is as follows:
A payroll is robbed. A man is killed. The
culprit is apprehended and tried by the community. The verdict: guilty. Justice has been
rendered by due process of law. But has it?
What about the fact that the evidence was purely
circumstantial, and that the condemned man
was a foreigner and an anarchist. But all appeals
are denied and the man is executed. Years later
the case is closed, even forgotten; for the public
believes that guilt is found only when no reasonable doubt exists. But then why does the judge
walk the streets like a madman, stopping people
with arguments? Why does a witness to the robbery who was never called to the stand fear for

in 1941 and a Ph. D. in 1948. In
1949 he joined the faculty of
the Boston University School of
Medicine.

1938, but until 1950 his works
were published solely in science
fiction magazines. His first book,

Lone Sophomore
Wins Television
In PM Contest
Dan Rosenfelt, Campus Student Representative for the
Philip Morris Company, announced last week that Harris
Belman and Phi Kappa Psi fraternity have won first and second prize, respectively, in the
"Round Up" contest which ended
November 16.
Heiman, a sophomore and a
resident of Baltimore, turned in
more than 4,000 empty cigarette
packages thereby winning a 19"
portable television set. When
asked by the News-Letter how
he managed to accumulate so
many packs, Heiman explained
that he encouraged all his friends
and relatives to collect empty
packages for him and that all
his empty packs were gathered
during the five week period of
the contest.
In awarding the television set
to Belman and a portable stereo
to Phi Kappa Psi, Dan Rosenfelt
noted that the individual initiative of Harris Heiman and the
members of Phi Kappa Psi had
prevailed over the efforts of much
larger groups. He added that
future Philip Morris promotions
will endeavor to encourage individual rather than group effort.

honored
misguided
rather
but
order here so that our well meaning
Student Council anti DSRC may reconsider the meaning
of the Code, their relation to it, their responsibility to
the student body, and finally the respect they owe, but
so infrequently show to the students they puport to represent.
In the first place the open jurisdictional conflict
between the DSRC anti the SC reminds one of the behavior of an "arrested adolescent who disarmingly
imagines that he will attain stature if (as short boys are
advised in Dixie) he loads enough manure into his
shoes." The petty jealousies surrounding this childish
squabble are entirely unnecessary and undermine the
very object which both groups seek to attain. The blame
for this sorry state of affairs rests with both groups, and
every effort should be made to cease from this innane
behavior.
Secondly, we note that by relegating the Code to a
trivial level the Council has seriously undermined the
Code's efficacy. The SC activities of the past week are an
example of this. There was no necessity for the Council
to try the petty offense of stealing a flag at a football
game. The very value of the Code lies partly in the
latitude of action it allows a Hopkins student. The Code
should only be invoked when the infraction warrants
serious action. Otherwise there will never be a shred of
respect for the Gentlemen's Code.
The attitude of many SC members in this and other
instances clearly shows their complete detachment from
the reality of student behavior. It should be recognized
that college students do not and cannot act in accordance
with the idealized and unrealistic image of a Gentleman
desired by certain members of our Hopkins community.
The welter of trivia passed in recent years by the SC
and DSRC testify to this fact. If a moral robot is desired
then we should apply to Pavlov and Skinner and abandon
the Gentlemen's Code.
This particularizing of the Gentlenten's Code stems
in part from the undue concern with publicity and public
relations which manifests itself throughout all levels of
the University. A reading of the version of the Gentlemen's Code contained in the present SC constitution reveals that "The Honor system governs... those aspects
of behavior among students on the campus, or at the
location of campus-sponsored activities, which might in
any way compromise or undermine the present valued
ethical concept of Hopkins men." But in the proposed
version of the Gentlemen's Code Commission we find
that its jurisdiction has been enlarged to world wide
coverage extending through all vacations. One wonders
if we won't have to sign out to relieve the University of
responsibility for our behavior after we graduate.
In conclusion we can only reiterate that we do not
disagree with the conception of a campus wide judicial
hoard. On the contrary, we initiated this idea in an editorial last spring. But we do take exception with the concepts and methods being used to accomplish this end.
We would suggest that both the DSRC and SC begin to
think before they act, that they consider the philosophy
underlying the Gentlemen's Code, and that they act appropriately.

Bravo!
The fraternity men among us should react with
pride in regard to the latest listing of their averages.
While the top fraternity has equaled its performance of
last year, the majority of fraternities have considerably
improved their levels of scholarship. A point in fact is
that one fraternity raised its average a tenth of a point
hut dropped two places in the listing. We would also
guess that the overall fraternity average has echoed this
trend and gone up considerably from last year. These
facts should help dispell the well worn conundrum that
membership in a fraternity hurts marks. Quite obviously
the Hopkins fraternities are mark conscious and effectively work to improve their grades.

school. "The collection includes both classical
and references books, and represents a typical

mustered up enough' courage to ask her the all-important

"Yes," she said simply. They shook hands then and squeezed
each other's shoulders and exchanged brave smiles, and if their
eyes were a trifle moist, who can blame them?
For a time things went swimmingly. Then a cloud appeared.
Mary Ellen, it seems, was a rich girl and accustomed to costly
pleasures. Poseidon was bone-poor and he quickly ran out of
money. Unable to take Mary Ellen to the posh places she
fancied and too proud to tell her the reason, he turned surly and
full of melancholy. Soon their romance, so promising at the
beginning, AVM headed for a breakup. But at the last moment,
Poseidon managed to blurt out the truth.
"Oh, beloved agrarian!" cried Mary Ellen, grappling him
close. "Oh, proud husbandman! Oh, foolish reaper! Why have
you not told me before? I have plenty of money, and I will
contribute according to my ability."
Poseidon, of course, protested, but she finally persuaded him
of the wisdom of her course. From then on they split all expenses
by
according to their incomes. Rather than embarrass Poseidon up
handing him money in public, a joint bank account was set
to allow him to write checks. Into this account each week they
faithfully deposited their respective allowances-35 cents from
Poseidon; $2300 from Mary Ellen.
And it worked fine! They were happy—truly happy! And

BIA President Cioni
Speaks On Intramurals
By LAWRENCE POLLAK
After successfully completing
its Fall sports program, the
Board of Intramural Athletics,
under President Joe Cioni, is now
getting its winter season into
full swing. The main function
of the BIA is the organization
and operation of an intramural
sports program for fraternities,
dormitory houses, and independents. The Board also serves as
a judicial body, deciding all disputes and protests that occur
during intramural games.
The BIA is a ten member
group made up of three Seniors,
three Juniors, and four Sophomores. During each sport seaBooks for sale—Encyclopedia

Distinguished from that which has practical application, pure research is concerned with the discovery of fundamental
knowledge to widen man's understanding
of himself and the universe.
Ford Motor Company's Scientific Laboratory in Dearborn, Michigan is dedicated
to the pursuit of knowledge in the physical
sciences. On its staff are scientists of
national and international reputation who
conduct independent basic research programs of an extremely broad nature.
Why does Ford Motor Company support
research which seemingly is unrelated to
the manufacture of its products?
It is our view, and a pioneering concept
in our industry, that entirely new approaches to automotive development can
come only from unhampered scientific
investigation. Deeper understanding of
matter itself, and of the conversion and
storage of energy—aside from widening
man's primary knowledge—may have
practical application in tomorrow's vehicle
design.
Thus knowledge wrested from nature by
scientists will be taken by technologists
and applied to serve practical needs and
desires. Another example of Ford's leadership through scientific research and
engineering.

When asked to comment on
the intramural program thus far
this year, President Cioni replied that "generally, things have
been running smoothly" and
that he was quite pleased with
the program. The main criticism
of the BIA so far this year, Cioni
explained, has been that there
hasn't been enough publicity
given to the schedule of the
games and as a result several
teams,
especially
fraternity
teams, did not show up for their
scheduled Fall sports games.
Cioni admitted that the BIA
was partly to blame for the
missed games as a result of poor
publicity, but he added; "Ten
days before the Fall program,
a meeting of all team athletic
managers was held and a schedule for the entire season was
presented; Some of the fraternity athletic managers did not
inform the fraternity of its
schedule of games. In an effort
to correct this, the BIA has
instituted a weekly bulletin,
which, besides listing a schedule
of the week's games, contains
up to date league standings.
Cioni also plans to make up next
Fall's schedule in April or May
to avoid any last minute confusion.
Cioni felt that another weakness in tile fall season was the
officiating. For the Intramural
Basketball games, referees will
be provided and they will be
paid $1.50 by the Athletic Department. Cioni added that he
would like to see the same thing
done in football and lacrosse,
but he felt that the referees
would probably have to be paid
by the teams themselves.
In an attempt to clarify certain BIA rulings, Cioni stated
that there are no forfeits allowed in the Fraternity leagues
and, if a team forfeits 25% of
its games, it will be dropped
from the league. Also, anyone is
eligible for BIA sports in a particular season, if he is not playing an intercollegiate sport in
that season.

HopkinsUniversity
Releases Non-toxic
Dye in River
On Friday, December 1, a
non-toxic, red fluorescent liquid
dye will be pumped into Round
Bay on the Severn River as part
of a study of water circulation
by the Johns Hopkins University's Chesapeake Bay Institute.
The dye will be released continuously for twenty-one days
from the Institute's research
vessel, the Maury, anchored in
Round Bay.
Dr. Donald W. Pritchard, director of the Institute, said that
the dye will be visible by residents in the area for a few hundred yards from the point of
release. He stated that the color
will not be visible to the eye as
it spreads out into the Chesapeake Bay. The dye is in no
way harmful to people, plants,
or animals. It will not discolor
or harm the paint finish on hulls
of boats.
The dye to be released is a
commercial pigment, rhodamine
B, used in such things as lipstick and pink birthday candles.
As the dye spreads through
the waters of Round Bay, its
concentration and
movement
will be continuously recorded by
two vessels of the Hopkins
Chesapeake Bay Institute, the
Lydia Louise II and the Tracer.
After the dye has been dispersed by the currents, water
will be drawn up through a tube
into the laboratory ships. There
it will pass through an instrument specially designed to measure the concentration of the
dye.
This study is the first in a
projected series of investigations of water movement and
dispersion being conducted by
the Hopkins scientists in order
to gain a better foundation for
understanding what happens to
treated sewage after discharge
into the Chesapeake Bay or one
of its tributaries.
Dr. James H. Carpenter, Hopkins' oceanographer, devised this
method of tagging water with
rhodamine B.
Dr. Carpenter said that oceanographers have carried out
laboratory studies on many
kinds of chemicals to be released
as tagging elements in water
which could be followed for
mile as tile water circulated and
mixed. Some chemicals were
found to be toxic. Others were
too weak to be followed by the
most delicate of detecting instruments. Still others disappeared
too fast. Rhodamine B, has
proved to be non-toxic, longlasting and easily detected for
long periods of time.
